div.head: Introduction
div.p: TEI Rails is a content management system for documents encoded in TEI. It is written in Ruby on Rails. Development funding for the project came from a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities at the University at Buffalo. The content management system is intended to run the Litgloss archive, which is a collection of texts in a variety of languages which are annotated for pedagogical purposes.

div.head: Features
div.p: TEI Rails has a number of features which make storing and collaborating on documents encoded in TEI easier. These features include support for document versioning, media file storage with associated documents, a workflow which facilitates collaboration, and advanced features for document annotation.
TEI Rails supports document versioning. The system stores all versions created of a particular document, and authorized users may revert to previous versions at any time.

The system also supports a hierarchy of users and workflow for collaboration. Without customization, the default hierarchy allows for classes of users considered to be system administrators, editors, contributors, and normal users.

TEI Rails allows for users to collaborate on documents by creating private "clones" of those documents. A clone is basically a shallow copy of a document into a private workspace of a user. Once a user and editor are satisfied with her changes, an editor may pull from these local changes and modify the public content item. This approach to document workflow, which allows for "clusters" of document clones around a central document object, allows for a secure system while also providing a "sandbox" where users less familiar with TEI may try their changes safely.

Multiple forms of "annotation" are supported. TEI Rails supports many forms of document markup. Of course, annotations may be made to a document according to the TEI guidelines for P5 and the TEI Lite DTD. In addition to this, TEI Rails includes a web-based editor which automatically inserts "annotations" which show up on a rendered page with a javascript popup. These are handy fo allowing users to add notes to a document with a particular knowledge of TEI or XML.

TEI Rails also includes an Annotea server, which allows for collaboration on documents through XPointer references to any rendered document in the TEI Rails system. This Annotea server was written as a Ruby on Rails plugin, and is shipped by default with TEI Rails installations. It is also available by itself for simple inclusion in other Ruby on Rails applications.
TEI Rails supports image and audio uploads to be associated with content items and "litglosses" (the document markup tag mentioned above).

Finally, TEI Rails checks all input against a DTD for TEI Lite, and it passes errors from the validator to the user. No data are saved in the system if a document is not well-formed and able to be validated against a DTD.
